Physics and the Universe

The science of Physics goes beyond the limits of planet Earth and, through its studies, provides us with essential information about our universe.

Like any science, Physics is also directly connected to the language of mathematics. For this reason, we begin this section with Chapter 6 of the First Steps part, which is dedicated to the study of mathematics in connection with other sciences. Thus, we recommend reading the first five chapters of that section before continuing (History Tracers Team. First Steps).

Although in school we are introduced to subjects called Science or Physics before entering university, teaching often limits itself to presenting only the initial stages of this field. These stages could be referred to as proto-Physics or pre-Physics, as proposed by Dr. Francisco González A. Redondo (González Redondo, Francisco A., ; González Redondo, Francisco A., ; González Redondo, Francisco A., ; History Tracers Team, The knowledge).

In the texts of this section, we present the concepts of pre-Physics and proto-Physics, gradually connecting them to Physics through mathematics.
Chapter 1: The Origin of What We Observe

value.name: Shared Origin
value.desc: In this text, we take a journey back in time to understand what current measurements reveal about the universe’s past.

value.name: Simplicity vs. Complexity
value.desc: Despite more than 13.8 billion years of evolution of the universe, we often still wish to be like it was in its beginnings. Why?

value.name: Two sides
value.desc: good vs. evil, left vs. right, matter vs. energy, up vs. down. Is this duality enough?

value.name: Expanding...
value.desc: Continuing from the previous text, we see that dividing into just two sides ends up doing omissions

value.name: Always present
value.desc: many times we are so focused on ourselves or on opposites that we do not notice what is always present.

value.name: Evolution of Knowledge: The Atom
value.desc: In this text, we study how our idea of the atom has evolved over time.

value.name: The four divisions
value.desc: in addition to the four limbs of the human body, the number four has also been used in various contexts throughout the history of humanity.

value.name: Dividing again
value.desc: When we perform a division, we can repeat it — but how can we represent this idea in the language of mathematics?

value.name: Evolution of knowledge – The hydrogen atom
value.desc: Hydrogen is the smallest atom we know of; even so, inside it we can still find other particles.

value.name: Is this extra?
value.desc: In this text, we introduce the concept of a remainder in division.

value.name: Returning
value.desc: In this text, we present the subtraction operation as a form of return.

value.name: Cooking
value.desc: The preparation of food is often remembered for adding quantities, but there is also another side to it.

value.name: Practicing subtraction
value.desc: In this text, the reader is introduced to an application that generates random subtraction problems with descriptions of the calculation steps.

value.name: The Difference of Equals
value.desc: In this text, we study the mathematical operation that allows us to determine whether something is equal or not.

value.name: Nearly identical
value.desc: As atoms were generated in nature, some of them ended up so similar that we cannot tell them apart.

value.name: There is something else
value.desc: in this text, we return to the kitchen to check how much is left of the ingredients from a recipe.
